source:
# [MCB 32]: Lab 06 - Frog Heart Study --- ### Professor Robin Ball Using what you learned, you will create tables for the data you collected in this lab as well as the averaged class data. You will also graph the class data, so it is easier to visualize and find major trends. *Estimated Time: ~45 Minutes* --- ### Table of Contents 1. [Data Analysis](#section_1) a. [Entering your data](#section_1a) b. [Entering class data](#section_1b) c. [Graphing class data](#section_1c) ### Completing the Notebook
QUESTION cells are in blue and ask you to enter in lab data, make graphs, or do other lab tasks. To receive full credit for your lab, you must complete all QUESTION cells.
To run a code cell once it's been selected, - press Shift-Enter, or - click the Run button in the toolbar at the top of the screen. If a code cell is running, you will see an asterisk (*) appear in the square brackets to the left of the cell. Once the cell has finished running, a number will replace the asterisk and any output from the code will appear under the cell. To start, we will import the datascience package which comes with pre-defined tools that can be used to work with our data.

from datascience import *
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# 1. [Data Analysis](#section_1) You will use what you learned last week to create tables and graphs for this lab. If you need a refresher, you can always refer back to the previous lab notebooks. ### 1a. [Entering your data](#section_1a)
QUESTION Create tables for Table 1, 2, and 3 that contain the data you collected. For the sake of efficiency, "HR" refers to the heart rate and "amp" refers to the amplitude of R wave.
#### Table 1: Temperature Effects
t1_labels = ["Condition", "Human heart rate", "Baseline frog heart rate", "Warm temperature",
"Baseline before cold", "Cold temperature"]
